The first program (codeforces_61_B) reads three lines (each processed to remove non-alphabetic and convert to lower case) and then an integer n, followed by n lines of test cases (each similarly processed). Then it forms 6 permutations of the three words and for each test case, checks if the test case string is one of the permutations. It outputs "ACC" or "WA".

 2.

tree.original_reasoning:
We are going to chain two programs: 
 1. The first program (codeforces_61_B) reads three lines (each processed to remove non-alphabetic and convert to lower case) and then an integer n, followed by n lines of test cases (each similarly processed).
    Then it forms 6 permutations of the three words and for each test case, checks if the test case string is one of the permutations. It outputs "ACC" or "WA".

 2. The second program (atcoder_ABC132_A) reads one word and then checks if the word has exactly two distinct characters and each character appears exactly twice. Then it outputs "Yes" or "No".

 However, note that the second program does not use the output of the first. The problem says: "the output of each program is used as the input to the next".

 But in the provided example, the two programs are independent. How are we to chain them?

 Let me re-read: "Translate the entire sequence into a single C program that reproduces the same behavior."

 And: "the output of each program is used as the input to the next".

 So we have two programs: 
   Program1: reads input1 and produces output1 (which is a sequence of "ACC" and "WA" for each test case, each on a new line).
   Program2: reads input2 (a single string) and produces output2.

 The problem says the output of each program is the input to the next. Therefore, the output of Program1 (which is multiple lines) becomes the input to Program2.

 However, the second program expects a single string. This is a problem.

 Let me check the original programs:

 Program1: 
   Input: 
        Line1: word1
        Line2: word2
        Line3: word3
        Line4: n (number of test cases)
        Next n lines: test cases.

   Output: n lines (each either "ACC" or "WA")

 Program2:
   Input: a single string (via `in.next()`)

 So if we chain, the input to Program2 would be the entire output of Program1 (which is n lines of either "ACC" or "WA"). 

 But Program2 expects a string of 4 characters? (because the problem it solves is: given a string of length 4, check that there are exactly two distinct letters, each repeated twice).

 However, the output of Program1 for n=1 would be one line: either "ACC" or "WA" (which are 3 letters). For n>1, we have multiple lines.

   We'll do the same in C.

   Important: We assume the holy words and test cases are not too long (so 1000 characters should be enough).

   Let's write the C code accordingly.

   We'll create helper functions to clean a string: remove non-alphabet and convert to lower.

   Example clean function:

        void clean_string(char *str) {
            int j = 0;
            for (int i = 0; str[i]; i++) {
                if (isalpha(str[i])) {
                    str[j++] = tolower(str[i]);
                }
            }
            str[j] = '\0';
        }

   But note: the original Java uses `replaceAll("[^a-zA-Z]", "")` which removes non-alphabet. And then `toLowerCase()`. We do the same.

   Steps for the permutations:

        char perm1[3000], perm2[3000], ... up to perm6.

        sprintf(perm1, "%s%s%s", word1, word2, word3);
        ... etc.

   Then for each test case, clean the string and then compare to each perm.

   We assume the cleaned test case string is compared to the cleaned permutations (which are already cleaned).

   But note: the three holy words are cleaned individually, and then concatenated. The test case is cleaned. So we are comparing cleaned strings.

   Now, code structure:

        #include <stdio.h>
        #include <ctype.h>
        #include <string.h>
        #include <stdlib.h>

        void clean_string(char *str) {
            // in-place cleaning
            int j = 0;
            for (int i = 0; str[i]; i++) {
                if (isalpha((unsigned char)str[i])) {
                    str[j++] = tolower((unsigned char)str[i]);
                }
            }
            str[j] = '\0';
        }

        int main() {
            char word1[1000], word2[1000], word3[1000];
            fgets(word1, sizeof(word1), stdin);
            fgets(word2, sizeof(word2), stdin);
            fgets(word3, sizeof(word3), stdin);
            // Remove newlines from fgets? clean_string will remove them (since they are non-alpha) and also clean.
            clean_string(word1);
            clean_string(word2);
            clean_string(word3);

            int n;
            scanf("%d", &n);
            getchar(); // consume newline

            char test_cases[100][1000]; // assuming at most 100 test cases and each line up to 1000
            // But the problem doesn't specify bounds. We'll assume 1000 test cases and 1000 chars per line.

            // We'll use dynamic allocation? or fixed size: [1000][1000] -> 1e6 which is acceptable.

            // Alternatively, we can store the cleaned test cases in an array of strings.
            char cleaned_test_cases[1000][1000]; // we assume n<=1000

            for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) {
                fgets(test_cases[i], sizeof(test_cases[i]), stdin);
                // Clean in place? we can clean into cleaned_test_cases[i]?
                strcpy(cleaned_test_cases[i], test_cases[i]);
                clean_string(cleaned_test_cases[i]);
            }

            // Form the six permutations
            char perm1[3000], perm2[3000], perm3[3000], perm4[3000], perm5[3000], perm6[3000];
            sprintf(perm1, "%s%s%s", word1, word2, word3);
            sprintf(perm2, "%s%s%s", word1, word3, word2);
            sprintf(perm3, "%s%s%s", word2, word1, word3);
            sprintf(perm4, "%s%s%s", word2, word3, word1);
            sprintf(perm5, "%s%s%s", word3, word2, word1);
            sprintf(perm6, "%s%s%s", word3, word1, word2);

            // Array of the permutations for easy looping
            char *perms[6] = {perm1, perm2, perm3, perm4, perm5, perm6};

            // Now, for each test case, we'll check against the perms.
            // We are going to store the result for each test case in an array of strings: but we only need the first one for the next program.
            // However, we must compute all because the first program's logic does.
            // But note: the first program outputs for each test case.

            // We'll store the first result in a variable for the next program.
            char *first_result = NULL; // if n>=1, we will set this to either "ACC" or "WA"
            // But note: we cannot point to string literals because we are going to use it in the next program? We can just store the string.

            // Alternatively, we can store the first result in a fixed buffer.
            char first_token[4] = ""; // 3 letters and null terminator.

            for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) {
                int found = 0;
                for (int j = 0; j < 6; j++) {
                    if (strcmp(cleaned_test_cases[i], perms[j]) == 0) {
                        found = 1;
                        break;
                    }
                }
                if (i == 0) {
                    if (found) {
                        strcpy(first_token, "ACC");
                    } else {
                        strcpy(first_token, "WA");
                    }
                }
                // In the first program, it would have printed "ACC" or "WA" for each test case.
                // But we don't print, we just store the first one.
            }

            // If n==0, then first_token is still the empty string.

            // Now, run the second program on the string `first_token`
            // We'll build a frequency map for the characters in first_token.

            int freq[256] = {0}; // frequency counts for each char
            int len = strlen(first_token);
            for (int i = 0; i < len; i++) {
                unsigned char c = first_token[i];
                freq[c]++;
            }

            int distinct = 0;
            int all_two = 1;
            for (int i = 0; i < 256; i++) {
                if (freq[i] != 0) {
                    distinct++;
                    if (freq[i] != 2) {
                        all_two = 0;
                    }
                }
            }

            if (all_two && distinct == 2) {
                printf("Yes\n");
            } else {
                printf("No\n");
            }

            return 0;
        }
